questions.question_text: The distance between parallels of latitude 10°N and 11°N along a meridian is approximately:

options: Magnetic north and the aircraft’s magnetic heading
Magnetic north and the aircraft’s true heading

questions.question_text: An isogonal (isogonic) line on a navigation chart connects points of equal:

options: A line crossing all meridians at the same angle
A line crossing all parallels of latitude at the same angle
A line following a constant compass direction
The shortest path between two points on Earth
questions.correct_answer: A line crossing all meridians at the same angle

options: North geographic pole and North magnetic pole
The equator and the International Date Line

options: The direction the aircraft's nose is pointing
The direction of the aircraft’s motion over the ground
The direction of the north marker on the compass
The direction of the magnetic meridian
questions.correct_answer: The direction the aircraft's nose is pointing

questions.question_text: Magnetic deviation in a compass is the difference between:
options: The aircraft’s magnetic heading and compass reading
questions.correct_answer: The aircraft’s magnetic heading and compass reading

questions.correct_answer: Time-critical information on changes and hazards at airports or en route nav facilities

What does the acronym ADF stand for?

What does the acronym NDB stand for?

What does GNSS stand for?
What does WAAS stand for in the context of GPS?
What does RAIM stand for?

What is the primary advantage of GPS (GNSS) over VOR navigation?
options: Worldwide coverage without reliance on ground stations
questions.correct_answer: Worldwide coverage without reliance on ground stations

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes pilotage as a navigation method?
options: Navigating by reference to visible landmarks
Navigating using time, speed, and heading calculations
questions.correct_answer: Navigating by reference to visible landmarks

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes dead reckoning as a navigation method?
options: Navigating using calculations based on speed, time, and heading
questions.correct_answer: Navigating using calculations based on speed, time, and heading

questions.question_text: Dead reckoning navigation assumes that wind conditions remain:
options: Only at the end of flight

questions.question_text: On which type of map projection do great circle routes appear as straight lines?

Why is filing a VFR flight plan recommended?
options: Search and Rescue can know your route and ETA
It is required for any flight
It automatically clears you through controlled airspace
questions.correct_answer: Search and Rescue can know your route and ETA

questions.question_text: What is the minimum fuel reserve typically required for a VFR flight?
options: 30 minutes of fuel at normal cruise
questions.correct_answer: 30 minutes of fuel at normal cruise

questions.question_text: If weather deteriorates en route or at the destination, a prudent pilot should:
options: Plan a diversion to a suitable alternate airport and inform ATC
Continue to the destination at the expense of safety
Shut off communications and search for landmarks
Immediately climb to the highest altitude possible
questions.correct_answer: Plan a diversion to a suitable alternate airport and inform ATC

questions.question_text: ATIS stands for:

TAF stands for:

options: Current weather conditions, active runway, and airport information
questions.correct_answer: Current weather conditions, active runway, and airport information

questions.question_text: A METAR report provides:
options: Current observed weather at an airport
questions.correct_answer: Current observed weather at an airport

questions.question_text: A TAF report provides:
Which of the following is true: METAR vs TAF?
options: METAR is an observation (current weather) and TAF is a forecast
METAR is a forecast and TAF is a current observation
Both METAR and TAF are forecasts
Both METAR and TAF are historical observations
questions.correct_answer: METAR is an observation (current weather) and TAF is a forecast

questions.question_text: In a METAR report, CAVOK means:
options: Ceiling and visibility OK (>=10 km, no clouds below 5000 ft, no significant weather)
questions.correct_answer: Ceiling and visibility OK (>=10 km, no clouds below 5000 ft, no significant weather)

How many hours are in 30 minutes?

One degree of latitude on Earth equals how many nautical miles (approximately)?

If True Heading is 360°, variation 5°W, deviation 3°E, what is the compass heading?

options: To maintain a desired ground track despite wind drift
questions.correct_answer: To maintain a desired ground track despite wind drift

options: West is best, East is least
North and South are always the best
questions.correct_answer: West is best, East is least

questions.question_text: Which two factors cause an aircraft’s compass heading to differ from its true heading?
What is the wind correction angle?
options: The angle between heading and track to compensate for drift
The angle between ground track and magnetic north
The angle between true north and magnetic north
The bank angle needed to maintain heading
questions.correct_answer: The angle between heading and track to compensate for drift

questions.question_text: Ground speed is the aircraft’s speed:
options: Over the ground, including effect of wind
questions.correct_answer: Over the ground, including effect of wind

questions.question_text: True airspeed (TAS) refers to the aircraft’s speed:
Mercator projection is most useful for:
options: Drawn navigation charts where rhumb lines are straight
questions.correct_answer: Drawn navigation charts where rhumb lines are straight

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes pilotage?
options: Navigating by landmarks and visual references
Navigating by calculations of time and speed
questions.correct_answer: Navigating by landmarks and visual references

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes dead reckoning?
options: Navigating by time, speed, and heading
Navigating by sight of ground features
questions.correct_answer: Navigating by time, speed, and heading

questions.question_text: How many nautical miles are covered in 30 minutes at 120 knots?
How many nautical miles are covered in 45 minutes at 90 knots?

options: Subject to static interference and night effect
questions.correct_answer: Subject to static interference and night effect

questions.question_text: The frequency range for VOR navigation is:
The frequency range for NDB/ADF is:
You tune a VOR and want to be sure it's correct. You should:
options: Listen for the station’s Morse code identifier
questions.correct_answer: Listen for the station’s Morse code identifier

questions.question_text: What does the 'FROM' flag on a VOR indicator mean?
options: The aircraft is on the selected course from the station
The station is to the front of the aircraft
The aircraft should fly away from the station
The OBS is set to the airport inbound course
questions.correct_answer: The aircraft is on the selected course from the station

questions.question_text: A homing technique to an NDB is characterized by:
options: Constantly pointing the ADF needle to the aircraft’s nose
Adjusting heading to correct for wind
Flying directly away from the station
questions.correct_answer: Constantly pointing the ADF needle to the aircraft’s nose

questions.question_text: Tracking to an NDB means:
options: Adjusting heading to maintain a constant bearing
questions.correct_answer: Adjusting heading to maintain a constant bearing

questions.question_text: Which technique uses a constant aircraft heading and corrects track by drift correction?
A VOR station co-located with a DME is known as:
Magnetic heading plus relative bearing (to a station) equals:
Relative bearing is defined as:
options: The angle from the aircraft’s nose to the station
The bearing from the station to the aircraft
The difference between true and magnetic north
questions.correct_answer: The angle from the aircraft’s nose to the station

If relative bearing is 135° and magnetic bearing is 225°, what is the aircraft’s magnetic heading?
If relative bearing is 045° and magnetic bearing is 360°, what is the aircraft’s magnetic heading?
An aircraft using dead reckoning primarily relies on:
options: Time, speed, heading, and drift calculations
questions.correct_answer: Time, speed, heading, and drift calculations

What is 130 knots in kilometers per hour (approximately)?

options: True heading plus West variation or minus East variation
Only equal if variation is zero
questions.correct_answer: True heading plus West variation or minus East variation

questions.question_text: For a magnetic heading and deviation, the compass heading is:
options: Magnetic heading plus West deviation or minus East deviation
questions.correct_answer: Magnetic heading plus West deviation or minus East deviation

questions.question_text: Which factor would NOT be included in a dead reckoning navigation calculation?

options: Calculating position by time, speed, and heading
Using VOR radials to fix position
questions.correct_answer: Calculating position by time, speed, and heading

questions.question_text: How many minutes of time difference does 45° of longitude represent?

options: Turn into the wind by applying a wind correction angle
Ignore the wind and maintain heading
questions.correct_answer: Turn into the wind by applying a wind correction angle

questions.question_text: Which navigation method does NOT require reference to landmarks?

options: Time, speed, distance and wind calculations
questions.correct_answer: Time, speed, distance and wind calculations

options: Adjusting the rate of descent using flaps
Approaching with flaps down for shorter runway usage
questions.correct_answer: Approaching with flaps down for shorter runway usage

options: To divert to if the destination is not suitable
To land in case of engine failure
questions.correct_answer: To divert to if the destination is not suitable

questions.question_text: Which of these is NOT a commonly used navigation aid?
An aircraft's drift angle is defined as:
options: The angle between the heading and the ground track
The angle between true north and magnetic north
The angle between the runway and wind
questions.correct_answer: The angle between the heading and the ground track

questions.question_text: What effect does an 180 knot tailwind have on the time to cover a fixed distance, compared to no wind?

options: Bearing to/from the station in the form of radials
Distance to the station in NM
questions.correct_answer: Bearing to/from the station in the form of radials

You are flying toward the station on the selected course
You are east of the station
questions.correct_answer: You are flying away from the station on the selected course

options: About 1 NM from the station (slant range)
questions.correct_answer: About 1 NM from the station (slant range)

questions.question_text: Which is NOT a valid use of dead reckoning navigation?
options: Flying low over land with no instruments
Calculating position using drift, time, and speed
Estimating position after encountering a GPS outage
Navigating in clear VFR conditions with landmarks
questions.correct_answer: Flying low over land with no instruments

questions.question_text: On a sectional chart, which symbol indicates a towered airport?

options: Provide route and timing information for Search and Rescue
questions.correct_answer: Provide route and timing information for Search and Rescue

questions.question_text: Which method of navigation uses time, speed, direction, and wind to determine position?

Which method of navigation relies on calculations of wind, time, and speed?

Which method of navigation relies on angle and distance to a VOR and an NDB?
What does RNAV allow a pilot to do?
options: Fly direct routes without overflying ground stations
questions.correct_answer: Fly direct routes without overflying ground stations

questions.question_text: What does GNSS refer to in navigation?

options: Slant range distance to the station
questions.correct_answer: Slant range distance to the station

questions.question_text: Which of these is NOT a component of total compass error?
Which factor causes magnetic deviation in a compass?
options: The difference between true and magnetic north

questions.question_text: Which factor causes magnetic variation on Earth?
options: Misalignment of magnetic and geographic poles
questions.correct_answer: Misalignment of magnetic and geographic poles

questions.question_text: Which of these instruments shows bearing to a VOR station?
Which of these instruments shows bearing to an NDB station?
In aviation navigation, the term "track" refers to:
options: The actual path of the aircraft over the ground
The direction the aircraft’s nose is pointing
The magnetic course set on the compass
questions.correct_answer: The actual path of the aircraft over the ground
